statements: If $(v_1, v_2)$ is good, then as $V$ varies over $\{(v_1,v_2)\} \times \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}_{>0}$, there are at least $\Gamma(v_1, v_2)$ possibilities for the function $\check{\Sigma}_{C,C}^V$.

Let $C = \{c_1, \dots, c_n\} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^d$. If the vector $v := M_C^{-1}\mathbf{1}$ has all entries strictly positive, then $\Psi(C)$ is the set of all $n!$ orderings of $C$, and every ordering is witnessed by a multiset of vantage points such that every vantage point is in $C$.
proofs:
Proof. Let $N = \Gamma(v_1, v_2)$. Let $\Xi$ be the set of quadruples $(c_1, c_2, c_3, c_4) \in C^4$ such that
$$ 1 < \frac{\|v_2 - c_3\|}{\|v_2 - c_4\|} < \frac{\|v_1 - c_1\|}{\|v_1 - c_2\|}. $$
For $i \in \{1,2\}$, each element of $\Delta(v_i)$ is associated with a unique ordered pair of elements in $C$ since $|\Delta(v_i)| = \binom{|C|}{2}$. So $|\Xi| = N$. Lemma 6.4 tells us that for $\xi = (c_1, c_2, c_3, c_4) \in \Xi$, there is a unique $x_\xi \in \mathbb{R}$ such that
$$ \frac{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_1\|}(x_\xi)}{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_2\|}(x_\xi)} = \frac{\|v_2 - c_3\|^2}{\|v_2 - c_4\|^2}. $$
Moreover, since $(v_1, v_2)$ is good, these $x_\xi$'s are all distinct. Now order the elements of $\Xi$ as $\xi^{(1)}, \dots, \xi^{(N)}$ so that
$$ x_{\xi^{(1)}} < \dots < x_{\xi^{(N)}}. $$
Write $\xi^{(j)} = (c_1^{(j)}, c_2^{(j)}, c_3^{(j)}, c_4^{(j)})$ and $x_j = x_{\xi^{(j)}}$. Choose arbitrary real numbers $x'_1, \dots, x'_N$ such that $x_1 < x'_1 < x_2 < x'_2 < \dots < x_N < x'_N$. For each $j$, we have
$$ \frac{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_1^{(j)}\|}(x'_j)}{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_2^{(j)}\|}(x'_j)} > \frac{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_1^{(j)}\|}(x_j)}{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_2^{(j)}\|}(x_j)} = \frac{\|v_2 - c_3^{(j)}\|^2}{\|v_2 - c_4^{(j)}\|^2} $$
by construction, so we can find some $y_j > 0$ such that
$$ \vartheta_{\|v_1-c_2^{(j)}\|}(x'_j) < y_j\|v_2 - c_4^{(j)}\|^2 < y_j\|v_2 - c_3^{(j)}\|^2 < \vartheta_{\|v_1-c_1^{(j)}\|}(x'_j). $$
Let $V_j = (v_1, v_2, x'_j, y_j)$. Note that $\check{D}_{V_j}(c) = \vartheta_{\|v_1-c\|}(x'_j)$ and $\check{D}_{V_j}(c) = y_j\|v_2 - c\|^2$. So the previous string of inequalities reads
$$ \check{D}_{V_j}(c_2^{(j)}) < \check{D}_{V_j}(c_4^{(j)}) < \check{D}_{V_j}(c_3^{(j)}) < \check{D}_{V_j}(c_1^{(j)}). $$
We claim that the $N$ functions $\check{\Sigma}_{V_j}^{C,C}$ are all distinct. Indeed, for $j' < j$, we cannot have
$$ \check{D}_{V_{j'}}(c_2^{(j)}) < \check{D}_{V_{j'}}(c_4^{(j)}) < \check{D}_{V_{j'}}(c_3^{(j)}) < \check{D}_{V_{j'}}(c_1^{(j)}) $$
since this would imply that
$$ \frac{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_1^{(j)}\|}(x'_{j'})}{\vartheta_{\|v_1-c_2^{(j)}\|}(x'_{j'})} > \frac{\|v_2 - c_3^{(j)}\|^2}{\|v_2 - c_4^{(j)}\|^2}, $$
contrary to the fact that $x'_{j'} < x_j$. Thus $\check{\Sigma}_{V_{j'}}^{C,C} \neq \check{\Sigma}_{V_j}^{C,C}$ for all $j' < j$, completing the proof.

Proof. Assume without loss of generality that the diameter of the set $C$ is at most $1/(10n)$. Let $c_{\sigma(1)}, \dots, c_{\sigma(n)}$ be an ordering of $C$, and define the vector $\mu \in \mathbb{R}^n$ coordinate-wise by $\mu_i := \sigma^{-1}(i)$. Then there is some constant $K > 0$ such that the vector $\rho := Kv + M_C^{-1}\mu$ has all entries strictly positive. Notice that $M_C\rho = K\mathbf{1} + \mu$. Obtain $\rho'$ from $\rho$ by rounding each coordinate down to the nearest integer. The key observation is that since each entry of $M_C$ is at most $1/(10n)$, each coordinate of $M_C\rho'$ differs by at most $1/10$ from the corresponding coordinate of $M_C\rho$. In particular, the coordinates of $M_C\rho'$, when ordered from smallest to largest, have the ordering $c_{\sigma(1)}, \dots, c_{\sigma(n)}$. Hence, if $V$ is the multiset consisting of $\rho'_i$ copies of each $c_i$, then $\Sigma_V^\sigma = (c_{\sigma(1)}, \dots, c_{\sigma(n)})$.
